0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate-commentary-idUSKCN1251CJ	Commentary: Manic or evasive - these veep guys sure donâ€™t feel like leaders	"
By Harold Meyerson
After going through a week reminiscent of Napoleon's at Waterloo
column2: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump will likely claim that Indiana Governor Mike Pence's performance in Tuesday's vice-presidential debate gave a boost to their campaign.That would be overstating it.The debate probably changed few votes in the 2016 presidential election. The question is whether it will change any votes in the 2020 contest.In this year's race
column3: the debate was something of a wash. Virginia Senator Tim Kaine
column4: the Democratic vice-presidential nominee
column5: came across like an over-caffeinated prosecutorial chipmunk - interrupting at every occasion. And at moments that weren't occasions at all.A gentle soul who's uncomfortable in the attack-dog role that the Clinton campaign has assigned him
column6: Kaine plainly overcompensated by piping up whenever Pence sought to evade debate moderator Elaine Quijano's questions.And because Pence spent the evening evading
column7: Kaine spent the evening interrupting. Though at the start
column8: the interruptions actually preceded the evasions
column9: and often interrupted Quijano's interjections as well.Pence surely had the better podium manner (no great achievement)
column10: even if his response to all Kaine's and Quijano's questions about the true man of the hour - Trump - was to change the subject. Or
column12: to deny that Trump had said what

column1: When the 10-second clips are aired and re-aired
column2: Kaine's attacks on Trump and Pence's non-responses will redound mildly to Clinton's advantage.But what does the debate tell us about the future of both parties? Pence was surely playing to the GOP's religious right on Tuesday
column3: with his anti-choice religiosity.In that sense
column4: he was trying to supplant Texas Senator Ted Cruz as the Holy Rollers' favorite son in the 2020 Republican primaries. (I'm assuming
column5: of course
column6: that Trump will not be running for his second term.)Pence would bring some clear advantages to this contest. Unlike Cruz
column7: Pence didn't desert the party's nominee (though Cruz came slinking back last week and finally endorsed Trump). Pence hasn't waged a scorched-earth war against the Republican leadership. He doesn't bear a disquieting resemblance to Bela Lugosi. For all these reasons
column8: Pence will likely be the religious right's candidate to take on President Hillary Clinton in 2020.

column1: Should Pence become the nominee
column2: however
column3: the GOP standard-bearer would likely only widen the already-yawning gap between Republicans and a majority of the American electorate. The affirmation of traditional right-wing positions that Pence delivered last night - against progressive taxation and all regulation
column4: against a woman's right to choose - would yield the party precious little support among millennials
column5: who will be by far the largest age group in the 2020 electorate.As for Kaine
column6: it's hard to think of any wing of the Democratic Party that would flock to him as a future standard bearer after last night's gravitas-free performance. It's increasingly unclear why Clinton chose him to be her running mate
column7: because that apparently meant miscasting him as her surrogate Trump-attacker.In both his convention speech and his debate performance
column8: Kaine has shown himself not up to the task. Some alternatives to Kaine - Labor Secretary Tom Perez comes to mind - would clearly have been better suited to the role. Perez would also have been better suited to help Clinton win more support from the one constituency that she most needs to do better: millennials. Many still don't see Clinton as signifying any change or embodying the values that Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders championed.

column1: Kaine is a man of many virtues
column2: and certainly could step into the presidency if he had to. But as a candidate and as a politician able to speak to younger voters and the Sanderistas - that is
column3: the future of the Democratic Party - he's been distinctly underwhelming.Meanwhile
column4: Quijano jumped around
column5: one topic to another
column6: almost as manically as Kaine. Moderating is no easy job
column7: but it must be said that Quijano shaped an uncommonly disjointed evening.More important
column9: both her questions on the economy - still the American public's No. 1 concern - focused on the debt and balancing the budget. At a time when the disabling effects of economic inequality and the need for greater public investment in infrastructure are belatedly receiving the recognition they deserve - and when the candidates' differences on these and other economic issues are vast - the size of the debt was hardly the topic on which the public needed to hear from the candidates.Between Quijano's topic-hopping
column11: the debate flashed by as cacophonously and at times as incomprehensibly as a game of pinball.Despite all the clamor
column12: it was resoundingly clear by evening's end that Kaine is not the Democrats' future leader
column14: while he could be the Republicans'
column15: is not likely to be America's.

column1: About the Author
Harold Meyerson is executive editor of the American Prospect.
The views expressed in this article are not those of Reuters News."	['Sanders'

column3: 'Trump'
column4: 'Pence'
column5: 'Cruz'
column6: 'Kaine']	[]

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-puertoricans-idUSKCN12522G	Florida's Puerto Ricans strongly favor Clinton: poll	"
By Luciana Lopez
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Florida's rapidly growing Puerto Rican population heavily favors Democrat Hillary Clinton over Republican Donald Trump in the U.S. presidential race
column2: according to a poll released on Wednesday by groups with links to the Democrats. Seventy-four percent of Puerto Ricans now registered to vote in Florida said they would likely pick Clinton in the Nov. 8 election
column3: versus 17 percent for Trump
column4: according to the poll from the Center for American Progress Action Fund and Latino Decisions.Puerto Ricans
column5: who traditionally lean toward voting Democratic in Florida
column6: are a big enough group to swing the closely-fought state.Florida
column7: the third-largest state in the country in terms of electoral college votes needed to win the White House
column8: has seen an influx of people from Puerto Rico
column10: as the Caribbean island's economy has floundered in recent years.

column1: More than one million Puerto Ricans now live in Florida
column2: according to the Pew Research Center
column3: making up about 5 percent of the total population.The Center for American Progress Action Fund is a progressive non-partisan organization that has been critical of Trump in the past. Latino Decisions has consulted for the Clinton campaign.       Florida is currently too close to call between Clinton and Trump
column4: according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project
column5: and both candidates have been focusing their campaigns there heading into the election.

column1: Trump angered many Hispanics when he launched his campaign last year by calling some Mexican immigrants rapists and drug dealers
column2: and his hardline immigration policies have done little to attract Latino voters.The poll did not gauge the level of eligible Puerto Rican voters who have registered in Florida
column3: an important measure given historically low Latino turnout. Latino voter registration lagged white and African-American voters in the 2014 congressional elections by 12 to 15 percentage points nationally
column4: according to the U.S. Census.

column1: But it said Puerto Rican voters now registered in Florida appeared motivated. Some 84 percent said they would definitely vote
column2: with another 14 percent saying they would probably do so. Only 2 percent said they definitely would not.The poll included 504 registered Puerto Rican voters in Florida with a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points. It was conducted from Sept. 17 to Sept. 26. (Reporting by Luciana Lopez; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Alistair Bell)"	['Clinton'
column3: 'Trump']	[]

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-france-juppe-idUSKCN1251VK	Potential next French president Juppe says Trump 'a big worry'	"
PARIS The prospect Donald Trump could become president of the United States is ""a big worry
column2: Alain Juppe
column3: the pollsters favorite to become President of France next year
column4: was quoted as saying on Wednesday.""I don't know Mr Trump
column5: but there's a question mark and a big worry
column6: Juppe
column7: who hopes to be the main candidate of the country's center right in April's presidential elections
column8: told the magazine Paris Match.""His total ignorance of Europe
column10: his isolationist and protectionist points of view
column13: are a real concern. But it is for the people of the United States to choose.""

column1: Trump is the Republican Party candidate for the U.S. presidential elections on Nov. 8.
(Reporting by Sophie Louet; writing by Andrew Callus; Editing by Leigh Thomas)"	['Trump']	[]
3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-wells-fargo-accounts-business-exclusi-idUSKCN124261	Exclusive: Wells Fargo account scandal extends to small business - U.S. senator	"
By Suzanne Barlyn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The scandal over improper sales practices at Wells Fargo & Co extended to thousands of small-business owners
column2: according to a U.S. lawmaker
column3: raising questions about the scope of the bank's issues with unauthorized accounts.In a Sept. 29 letter viewed by Reuters on Tuesday
column4: Sen. David Vitter
column5: a Louisiana Republican
column6: demanded that Wells Fargo Chief Executive John Stumpf provide a ""full accounting"" of customers affected. Vitter is a member of the U.S. Senate's banking committee and also heads its small business committee.Discussions between congressional staffers and Wells Fargo ""have indicated that the fraudulent activity of your employees was not limited to Wells Fargo's consumer banking operations
column7: Vitter wrote. ""Thousands of small business owners were impacted by this fraud.""A person familiar with Vitter's probe say Wells has identified about 10
column8: 000 small business accounts that were subject to improper practices. Vitter spokeswoman Cheyenne Klotz declined to comment on specifics about those practices.Revelations of Wells Fargo's problems with small-business customers come almost a month after it reached a $190 million settlement over opening as many as 2 million accounts in retail customers' names without their knowledge. The bank has said it fired about 5
column9: 300 employees for improperly opening the accounts.The disclosures have caused a public furor
column10: with Stumpf facing heated questions before two congressional committees and other U.S. authorities launching investigations into the bank's sales practices
column11: including the Justice Department and the Labor Department.""While the vast majority of accounts in the settlement were consumer accounts
column12: to the extent there were small business accounts included
column13: all were previously reported in the total number of potentially impacted accounts
column14: said Wells spokeswoman Jennifer Langan. ""As stated earlier
column18: were part of our Retail Bank business.""A Consumer Financial Protection Board spokesman contradicted the Wells statement
column20: saying its figure of nearly 2 million accounts being affected did not include small business accounts.Wells is also battling lawsuits from former employees
column21: customers and shareholders related to the issue. In a second letter
column22: Vitter requested that the Small Business Administration's inspector general

column1: PACKAGES OF THREE
Senior bank executives have apologized for opening accounts customers did not request
column2: but characterized the issue as limited to relatively few customers and employees in the retail bank. Early results from Vitter's examination are the first hard sign that problems may extend further.Reuters also spoke to a former Wells employee
column3: and a lawyer representing former employees and a former and current Wells customer
column4: who described abusive sales practices with multiple business accounts.     Jose Maldonado
column5: a restaurant owner in Southern California who banked with Wells Fargo for 15 years
column6: said he discovered seven accounts after enlisting the help of his accountant. He initially closed extraneous ones
column7: and ultimately moved his remaining business to Bank of America Corp and JPMorgan Chase & Co.""I don't like Wells Fargo anymore. I don't feel comfortable
column8: Maldonado said in an interview. ""In the past
column9: there were sometimes crazy accounts without my permission.""

column1: Langan declined to comment on Maldonado's accounts.An ex-Wells Fargo business banker
column2: who declined to be identified
column3: said employees at his former branch were required to sell products to small business customers such as hair-salon owners and carpet cleaners in packages of three - regardless of whether they needed them.Those typically included accounts for checking
column4: credit card processing and payroll
column5: and were often linked to additional savings accounts
column6: said the former Wells banker. Bankers also tacked on business credit cards and were pressured to call a Wells insurance unit
column7: with the customer present
column8: to push business liability policies.    Langan
column10: said the bank discontinued those packages in April 2015.Attorney Jonathan Delshad filed two class-action lawsuits against Wells Fargo in September on behalf of former employees
column12: who say they were fired for refusing to create fake accounts to hit sales quotas. Wells suspended those quotas on Oct. 1.

column1: Other former Wells Fargo business bankers contacted Delshad after the lawsuit received media attention
column2: he said. ""Business owners are also being ripped off
column3: one wrote to him in a message he provided to Reuters.SOURED RELATIONSHIPS

column1: Business and corporate governance experts say small-business customers can be as susceptible to fraud as any customer. Owners are typically knowledgeable about their business expertise but not about banking services
column2: said Peter Conti-Brown
column3: a financial regulation professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. For example
column4: a new dentist who borrows from a bank to buy a practice may then need other services that she does not even know exist
column5: such as payroll management or credit-card clearing.But the potential for abuse still exists
column6: he said. A bank can sell multiple
column7: unnecessary accounts and credit cards to sole proprietors whose needs rarely exceed making deposits and writing checks. The risk of abuse is greater when bankers are required to sell a certain number of products to meet performance goals.""The best case is that you will sour your relationship
column10: Conti-Brown said. ""Wells Fargo has seen both of these things."" (This article corrects the lede to add the dropped word ""of"") (Reporting by Suzanne Barlyn; Editing by James Dalgleish
column11: Lauren Tara LaCapra and Brian Thevenot)"	['Vitter']	[]

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN12505O	Clinton hits Trump over comments on women ahead of vice presidential debate	"
By Amanda Becker
| HAVERFORD
column2: Pa.

column1: HAVERFORD
column2: Pa. Democrat Hillary Clinton slammed Republican Donald Trump on Tuesday for making disparaging comments about women's physical appearance
column3: accusing Trump of taking the issue of female body image ""to a new level of difficulty and meanness.""Hours before vice presidential candidates Tim Kaine and Mike Pence face off in Virginia in their sole debate
column4: Clinton urged women at an event in the Philadelphia suburbs billed as a ""family town hall"" to stand up to online bullying about how they look.""It's shocking when women are called names and judged solely on the basis of physical attributes
column5: the Democratic presidential nominee said in response to a 15-year-old girl's question about the problem of body image and the ""damage Donald Trump does"" when he talks about how women look.""My opponent insulted Miss Universe
column6: Clinton said
column7: resurrecting her Republican rival's comments last week about former beauty queen Alicia Machado's weight gain after she won the Miss Universe contest in 1996.""I mean
column8: how do you get more acclaimed than that? But it wasn't good enough
column9: Clinton said. ""We can't take any of this seriously anymore. We need to laugh at it. We need to refute it.""Clinton
column10: the first woman to be nominated for the presidency by a major U.S. party
column11: has rushed to capitalize on Trump's public feud with Machado
column12: whom he once called ""Miss Piggy"" because of her weight gain
column13: and make inroads with women voters five weeks before the Nov. 8 election.Clinton's and Trump's running mates
column18: will meet in a debate in Farmville
column20: starting at 9 p.m. on Tuesday (0100 GMT on Wednesday.) The debate will provide voters their first extended chance to evaluate the No. 2's in the White House race and is the only showdown between the vice presidential candidates. Trump and Clinton will meet in their second debate on Sunday.Pence could find himself frequently on the defensive about Trump
column21: a New York businessman who has been dealing with a torrent of bad news in the past week.

column1: That includes a New York Times report that Trump took an almost $1 billion loss in 1995 that may have allowed him to avoid paying federal income taxes for up to 18 years. While Democrats have slammed him over the report
column2: Trump
column3: who made much of his business acumen on the campaign trail
column4: has said he ""brilliantly used"" U.S. tax rules to his advantage to limit his tax bills.Clinton disagreed
column5: telling reporters on Tuesday it showed ""unequivocally"" that Trump was a failure at business for losing $1 billion to begin with.A Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Tuesday said 67 percent of Americans believed it was ""selfish"" for a presidential candidate to pay no taxes
column6: although 46 percent thought a candidate who paid no taxes was ""smart.""'HARMFUL COMMENTS'

column1: Clinton also criticized Trump for appearing to suggest on Monday that veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress were not strong enough to handle the stress of war. Trump and his campaign said his words were taken out of context.""When people come back from war and combat
column2: and they see things that maybe a lot of folks in this room have seen many times over - and you're strong and you can handle it - but a lot of people can't handle it
column3: Trump told a veterans group on Monday.Clinton said troops deserved a commander in chief who understood their sacrifice.""Donald Trump's comments are not just ignorant
column4: they are harmful because they give voice to the stigma that has led generations of veterans to hide their struggles instead of getting lifesaving help
column5: she said.

column1: On the campaign trail on Tuesday
column2: Trump met with about a dozen energy executives in Denver
column3: querying them mainly about their concerns about regulations he said had ""gotten out of control.""John Harpole
column4: chief executive of Mercator Energy
column5: said he did not understand why the Obama administration's response to the shale boom and Clinton's energy positions had not come up during the first presidential debate last week.Others told Trump they faced more immediate concerns with state-level regulators. Scott Stewart of Gilbert-Stewart Operating said his company had largely moved operations to Kansas because of stiff rules in Colorado.Trump also reveled in comments on Monday by Clinton's husband
column6: former President Bill Clinton
column7: who said small-business people and people who make too much to get federal subsidies to help with insurance payments were ""getting killed"" by the federal healthcare law known as Obamacare.Trump has promised to repeal Obamacare
column8: while Hillary Clinton has praised it but said she would work to improve aspects of it.""I bet he went through hell last night
column9: can you imagine?"" Trump said of Bill Clinton during a rally in Prescott
column11: but honestly there have been many nights when he has gone through hell with Hillary.""Clinton has led Trump in national opinion polls in recent months. On Tuesday
column12: an average of polls aggregated by RealClearPolitics website showed her with 48.1 percent of support compared with Trump's 44.3 percent. (Writing by John Whitesides; Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson in Colorado and Chris Kahn in New York; Editing by Frances Kerry and Peter Cooney)"	['Kaine'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-illinois-idUSKCN12502O	Same-day voter registration temporarily reinstated in Illinois	"
An Illinois law allowing voters in highly populated areas to register to vote at polling places on election day was reinstated on Tuesday by a federal court
column2: pending an appeal of a ruling declaring the statute unfair to people in smaller communities.The state is seeking to overturn a ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Samuel Der-Yeghiayan
column3: which found that the law discriminates against voters in less-populated counties.The law
column4: passed in late 2014 by the Democratic-led legislature and signed into law in early 2015 by former Democratic Governor Pat Quinn
column5: allowed election day voter registration for the first time
column6: including at polling places.But the section of the law regarding polling place registration pertained only to counties with populations of 100
column7: 000 or more.

column1: The conservative Liberty Justice Center
column2: of Chicago
column3: filed a lawsuit in August
column4: saying the law was discriminatory. Der-Yeghiayan agreed
column5: writing that the law provided an advantage to urban voters over their rural counterparts. The state of Illinois appealed the ruling last month
column6: and in their order issued Tuesday
column7: a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted the state's request to stay the order until the appeal was adjudicated

column1: U.S. voters will go to the polls to choose a president
column2: Congressional representatives and other officials on Nov. 8. On Tuesday
column3: the appellate court ordered attorneys on both sides to say by Thursday whether they would like the appeals process to be sped up due to the proximity of the election.

column1: (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Lisa Shumaker)"	[]	[]
7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-inversions-idUSKCN1242FN	Proposed U.S. anti-inversion rules enter final review	"
By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. regulations
column2: proposed by the Treasury to crack down on companies that try to reduce taxes by rebasing abroad
column3: have begun a White House review and could be finalized shortly
column4: officials said on Tuesday.The regulations
column5: which would make it difficult for U.S. business operations to avoid taxation while shifting profits overseas through a practice called ""earnings stripping
column6: were received by the White House Office of Management and Budget (OMB) last week. The agency has up to 90 days to decide whether the rules should be finalized or returned to Treasury for further consideration.""We are satisfied we have addressed stakeholder feedback and are close to issuing final earnings stripping regulations
column7: a Treasury spokesperson said.

column1: The Obama administration has faced widespread criticism from the business community over its regulatory assault on tax inversions
column2: which are tax-driven mergers in which a U.S. company acquires a smaller
column3: foreign business in a low-tax country and shifts its headquarters there
column4: if only on paper
column5: to avoid higher U.S. taxes.   Business and industry groups have threatened lawsuits and called for the new rules to be withdrawn or heavily revised because of what critics say is the potential for unintended harm to business. Members of Congress have also accused the administration of overstepping its legal authority.

column1: Earnings stripping occurs when an inverted company eludes U.S. taxes on its domestic operation by shifting profits overseas in the form of tax-deductible interest payments to its foreign parent. The new rules would change certain interest payments into equity dividends
column2: which are not tax deductible in the United States.

column1: The regulations were proposed in April
column2: along with a temporary rule to prevent serial inversion deals by foreign companies. That rule
column3: which is already the target of a lawsuit
column4: has not yet been forwarded to OMB. (Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Obama']	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN1242FH	Trump calls tax avoidance 'smart
column2: ' most Americans call it 'unpatriotic': poll	"

column1: By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump says paying no income tax would make him ""smart."" While nearly half of Americans agree with him
column2: more people think it is ""selfish
column3: and ""unpatriotic
column4: according to a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Tuesday. Some 67 percent of Americans said it is ""selfish"" for a presidential candidate to pay no taxes
column5: while 61 percent said it is ""unpatriotic
column6: according to the poll
column7: which allowed respondents to pick more than one adjective to describe paying no taxes.At the same time
column8: the results showed some respect for a candidate who can figure out how to reduce their tax bill. Some 46 percent of Americans
column9: including 35 percent of Democrats and 62 percent of Republicans
column10: thought a presidential candidate who pays no taxes is ""smart.""Trump's taxes have become a big campaign issue after the New York Times released a portion of his 1995 tax returns last week and estimated that Trump likely paid no taxes for a number of years. The celebrity real estate developer
column11: who is the first presidential candidate in decades to refuse to release his full tax returns
column12: didn't deny the report. He later said that he had ""brilliantly used"" U.S. tax rules to his advantage. During the first presidential debate with his rival Democrat Hillary Clinton last month
column13: Trump responded to Clinton's allegation that he paid no federal taxes by saying that would make him ""smart.""

column1: What is he trying to say: that those of us who pay taxes aren't intelligent?"" said poll respondent Yonna McNerney
column3: of Denver. ""I started working at the age of 16
column4: and I've always paid taxes
column5: she said. ""Not paying taxes
column6: I don't think that's acceptable.""McNerney
column7: a mother of three who works at a telecommunications company
column8: remains uncommitted in the race and said Trump's comments about taxes haven't changed her mind one way or the other.April St. Aoro
column10: who works for a manufacturing firm near St. Cloud
column12: was more understanding of Trump's point of view
column13: though she also remains undecided in the race.

column1: I think all of us are trying to pay as little taxes as possible
column2: St. Aoro said.Respondents were slightly less critical when asked to describe a private citizen paying no taxes.Some 64 percent agreed it was ""selfish
column3: while just over half agreed it was ""unpatriotic."" Some 50 percent
column4: including 37 percent of Democrats and 67 percent of Republicans
column5: agreed that it was ""smart.""

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English in all 50 states. Respondents were asked what they thought of ""a private citizen who has found a way to pay no income taxes
column2: and given the choice to agree or disagree to the words ""smart
column3: ""selfish
column4: and ""unpatriotic."" They were then asked the same set of questions about a presidential candidate.The Sept. 28-Oct. 3 poll was part of a larger national tracking poll that tracks public opinion every day. It included 1
column5: 948 American adults
column6: including 893 Democrats and 635 Republicans. It has a credibility interval
column7: a measure of accuracy
column8: of 3 percentage points for the entire sample
column9: 4 percentage points for Democrats only and 5 percentage points for Republicans. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Ross Colvin)"	['Clinton'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-taxes-idUSKCN1232E3	Trump says he 'brilliantly' used U.S. tax laws	"
By Emily Stephenson
| PUEBLO
column2: Colo.

column1: PUEBLO
column2: Colo. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump said on Monday he ""brilliantly used"" U.S. tax rules to his advantage in trying to limit the amount he paid in taxes
column3: arguing it helped him survive a difficult period in the real estate market.""I was able to use the tax laws of this country and my business acumen to dig out of the real estate mess ... when few others were able to do what I did
column4: Trump told a crowd in Pueblo
column5: Colorado.It was Trump's first extended comments since a New York Times report said he had claimed a $916 million loss on his 1995 tax returns
column6: which experts said might have allowed him to avoid paying federal income taxes for 18 years. Hillary Clinton
column7: the Democratic nominee for the Nov. 8 election
column9: arguing the tax records undercut Trump's business acumen. ""What kind of genius loses a billion dollars in a single year? This is Trump to a T
column10: he's taken corporate excess and made a business out of it
column11: Clinton told a rally in Toledo

column1: Clinton has repeatedly called on Trump to release his full returns
column2: as presidential candidates have done in the past. Trump was dismissive of the Times' story in his Pueblo remarks
column3: saying the media was ""obsessed with an alleged tax filing from the 1990s.""

column5: including former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie have contended that Trump's aggressive use of provisions under U.S. law to minimize his tax liability was evidence of his ""genius"" as a businessman and real estate investor.Trump picked up on that theme on Monday. ""I have brilliantly used those laws
column6: he told the crowd in Pueblo.The flap over Trump's taxes comes during what has been a difficult stretch for the candidate
column7: who faced criticism for his performance in the Sept. 26 debate against Clinton and his subsequent public spat with former Miss Universe Alicia Machado.
